intro: Gilia copiapina, commonly known as the copiapó gilia, is a flowering plant native to the Atacama Desert in Chile. It is characterized by its striking, showy flowers that range in color from pink to purple, often with a distinctive red or orange throat. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to the extreme aridity of its environment. It produces small, oval-shaped fruits that contain numerous seeds. Gilia copiapina plays an important role in the local ecosystem, providing nectar for pollinators and contributing to the biodiversity of the desert flora.
